quoteFirst: In the meantime, I asked the lawyer if he had taken note of the fact that the pawnbroker’s time by the clock had made it impossible that Miss Frick could be back at Villa Ballarat at the time when the photograph was taken.  According to the pawnbroker’s account, she drove from there
quoteLast: , and the clock in the photograph showed it to be twenty minutes to six.  The way from Bishop Road to Villa Ballarat cannot be covered in five minutes.
title: The Black Tortoise: Being the Strange Story of Old Frick's Diamond
author: Sparre, Christian, 1859-1940; Brækstad, Gertrude Hughes [Translator]

quoteFirst: When the interesting conversation which has been narrated began, it was a quarter before three in the afternoon. It was at a quarter before four that Van Tricasse lighted his enormous pipe, which could hold a quart of tobacco, and it was at
quoteLast: that he finished smoking it.
title: A Winter Amid the Ice, and Other Thrilling Stories
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteFirst: Similar groups of fast-moving blips appeared at intervals during a period of about five minutes, and appeared also on two auxiliary radarscopes. After the first set was calibrated, the blips reappeared; none was observed after
quoteLast: From the radar data estimates of size and distance were made; calculations based on these estimates indicated a probable speed of 5000 to 9000 miles an hour. During the ten-minute period two visual observations were made, lasting about three seconds, which bore no obvious relation to the radar observations: at the right of the plane one crewman saw a single blue-white streak going from front to rear under the wing, and another crewman saw two flashes of blue-white light.
title: The World of Flying Saucers: A Scientific Examination of a Major Myth of the Space Age
author: Menzel, Donald H. (Donald Howard), 1901-1976; Boyd, Lyle Gifford, 1907-1982

quoteFirst: Changing the time of zero, the attack was renewed at
quoteLast: on the 15th October, the 18th Infantry Brigade on the left (2nd D.L.I. and 11th Essex) attempting to seize those portions of Cloudy and Mild trenches still held by the enemy, while the Sherwood Foresters on their right attacked some gun pits which lay about 200 yards in front of their line.
title: A Short History of the 6th Division: Aug. 1914-March 1919
author: Marden, Thomas Owen, Sir, 1866- [Editor]

quoteFirst: [Illustration: _(
quoteLast: workman's train.)_
title: Punch, or the London Charivari, Volume 146, January 7, 1914
author: Various

quoteFirst: You then take the main Carlisle road and proceed south on it. As you go you inspect all bridges, railroad tracks, streams, and ground in general for eight hundred yards on either side of the road, but find no enemy. At
quoteLast: you begin your message at the Stiner House. Before you now go south, you investigate for eight hundred yards the roads leading to the east and west from the main cross-roads south of Stiner.
title: The English of military communications
author: Ganoe, William Addleman, 1881-1966

quoteFirst: Changing the time of zero, the attack was renewed at
quoteLast: on the 15th October, the 18th Infantry Brigade on the left (2nd D.L.I. and 11th Essex) attempting to seize those portions of Cloudy and Mild trenches still held by the enemy, while the Sherwood Foresters on their right attacked some gun pits which lay about 200 yards in front of their line.
title: A Short History of the 6th Division: Aug. 1914-March 1919
author: Marden, Thomas Owen, Sir, 1866- [Editor]

quoteFirst: Wayne’s own duties didn’t begin until eight, and in consequence he had two hours on his hands that he didn’t know what to do with. Breakfast was always over by half-past five and a minute or two later June was streaking across the field to the railroad track. At about
quoteLast: there was a milk train due and June had become an adept at swinging himself to a platform as it slowed down at the yard entrance. Just at first his presence, when discovered, was resented, but presently the train hands good-naturedly failed to see him and he rode into town huddled up on a car step.
title: Second Base Sloan
author: Mathewson, Christy, 1880-1925; Caswell, Edward C., 1879-1963 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: On 9th February we started at
quoteLast: , and marched two hours and a half through a very beautiful undulating country, diversified with rocks, streams, and handsome park-like timber.
title: Ismailia
author: Baker, Samuel White, Sir, 1821-1893

quoteFirst: We started at
quoteLast: , and marched ten miles, and halted at a small ravine of running water among wooded hills.
title: Ismailia
author: Baker, Samuel White, Sir, 1821-1893

quoteFirst: This morning the natives commenced by throwing stones at the men who went down for the water, but we did not see any method of resenting it, except by expressing our disapprobation in words, and at
quoteLast: we started on a north-north-west course, the natives followed for about a mile, and continued throwing stones at the party. The country passed over was generally grassy granite hills till 9.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: You have not gone far, however, before you spy a low heavy cloud of dust ahead which seems to be moving toward you. At the Boyd School House Cross Roads it turns west at
quoteLast: . It takes the column, which you now make out to be infantry in column of squads, three minutes and forty seconds to pass the cross-roads (175 Infantry in column of squads can pass a given point in one minute). Since the patrols of the enemy are becoming rather thick, you decide to make your way back to the “K” in Stock Farm.
title: The English of military communications
author: Ganoe, William Addleman, 1881-1966
